Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Transcutaneous Electrical Acupoint Stimulation for PONV Prevention in Gynecological Laparoscopy

Background: Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is a common complication in gynecological laparoscopy. This study assesses the efficacy of single-period versus multiple-period transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation (TEAS) for PONV prevention.

Methods: Conducted at an academic medical center for women and children, this prospective, randomized, double-blind trial included 120 women, aged 18-65, undergoing gynecological laparoscopy. Participants were randomized into three groups: single-period TEAS (Group S, n=40), multiple-period TEAS (Group M, n=40), and non-stimulation control (Group C, n=40). Randomization was computer-generated with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes. Blinding included patients and outcome assessors. The primary outcome was PONV incidence and severity within 48 hours post-surgery.

Results: Group M demonstrated a significant reduction in PONV incidence compared to Group C (10% vs. 50%, p<0.05) and Group S (10% vs. 17.5%, p<0.05). Group M also had lower pain scores and reduced rescue antiemetic use. No adverse events related to TEAS were reported. The analysis was per-protocol, with 120 participants completing the study. Recruitment occurred from December 2022 to June 2023.

Interpretation: Multiple-period TEAS is more effective than single-period TEAS in reducing PONV and postoperative pain in gynecological laparoscopy. This approach could enhance multimodal prophylactic antiemetic regimens. Further research is needed to optimize TEAS timing and duration.

Trial registration: Chinese Clinical Trials Registry, No. ChiCTR2200065802.

Funding: Not specified.
